Thank you, I wonder whether it is too confusing that the last filter in the chain can be disabled, but the output of the chain will always include this filter. This might be related to the concept of the preview in the filter manager which shows the output of the chain up to and including the currently selected filter. How should this be handled when the currently selected filter is disabled?

Disable a filter
Preview the output of the remaining items of the chain
Re-enable the filter

As the design goal is to preserve filter configuration, is this cycle guaranteed to be non-destructive? Can the step 2 alter the configuration of remaining active filters?
Last but not least, how should we call the active filter list once it can include inactive / disabled filters?

What i dont know is, the scriptEngines.

Do you mean that current interfaces don't know anything about filters which should be added, but made disabled?

The last disabled filter indeed included, it is clearly a bug, i missed that.
The filter manager preview shouled display the filtered result even when the currently selected filter is disabled. Its a feature not a bug. It can be useful if someone want to compare two filter output, ith the same preceeding chain.

Can the step 2 alter the configuration of remaining active filters?

Did you mean 3. Re-enable the filter? In some cases it is inevitable, as would be deleting and later added again.

Last but not least, how should we call the active filter list once it can include inactive / disabled filters?

Filter chain?

Do you mean that current interfaces don't know anything about filters which should be added, but made disabled?

column20:

column21:
I'm sorry for being slow these days as my spare time I can afford to spend on computer stuff is currently very limited.

The filter manager preview shouled display the filtered result even when the currently selected filter is disabled. Its a feature not a bug.

Sure, but in case of the selected disabled filter being the last in the chain, this introduces a discrepancy between the preview in the filter manager (which includes the disabled filter) and the preview in the main window (which excludes it). Both behave correctly in their own right, but the result feels inherently buggy for me.

Did you mean 3. Re-enable the filter?

No, I meant step 2, but I was partially wrong.
Many filters don't validate configuration during contruction phase, preview is safe for them. But quite a few filters validate configuration when the configuration dialog is opened. Replace Step 2 with "Configure a filter farther down in the filter chain" and this step may become destructive.

Load a 1280x720 video with a logo in the top left corner
Rotate it to 270° (this moves the logo to the bottom left corner)
Add mpdelogo2, configure it to remove the logo in the bottom left corner
Preview the final result
Disable rotate
Open mpdelogo2 configuration dialog, accept it.
Re-enable rotate
Preview the final result

Actual results: the picture at step 4 and at 8 is not the same.
This is nothing new as moving filters around can have the same effect, but this points to what I perceive to be the real issue which needs a solution (with the premise behind the feature to allow to disable active filters taking at symptoms): it would be great to have a proper undo/redo functionality for the filter chain similar to segment layout in the editor. This would naturally provide the feature to disable a filter by simply deleting it as this step will be immediately reversible.


Last but not least, how should we call the active filter list once it can include inactive / disabled filters?

Filter chain?

Not quite, as the filter chain needs to be created without disabled filters...

column21:
I still dont see the problem here. In your example i can change the rotation amount, or simply delete the filter, and it will bring the same outcome.
The undo/redo functionality would be great, but it is beyond my skill level. Besides that, it is not the same as the enable/disable functionality.
An example workflow where i would like this disable option (and undo/redo would'nt work):
There are frequent camera switching in a video, one camera angle is dark, the other not so much. Also i want cropping, then fit to (a common) size. I save the segments with a mezzanine encoder, then at the end i append them then encode with the final codec.
Now after every few seconds i need to readjust the crop (large displacement), delete the color/intensity adjuster filters, and add another filter. With a disable option i can use two exclusive crop filter, where only minor adjustment would needed, and i could keep the color filters for each scenario.

Sure, but in case of the selected disabled filter being the last in the chain, this introduces a discrepancy between the preview in the filter manager (which includes the disabled filter) and the preview in the main window (which excludes it). Both behave correctly in their own right, but the result feels inherently buggy for me.

The preview in the filter manager does not show the complete chain output, but the selected filter's.

column20:
Tested many scenarios, it looks like it works.
What i dont know is, the scriptEngines.
column21:
In your example i can change the rotation amount, or simply delete the filter, and it will bring the same outcome.

This is sort of expected when filters up the chain are reconfigured, but disabling and re-enabling suggests non-destructive, fully reversible operation, a promise it cannot keep.

The undo/redo functionality would be great, but it is beyond my skill level.

Your skill level is formidable. In a very rough draft of undo/redo functionality, we would probably need a memento in form of a container with items consisting of filter tag (uint32_t) and CONFcouple array for each filter in the chain. Adding/deleting a filter or altering filter configuration would create a new memento and push it onto undo stack. undo() would create another memento and push it onto redo stack, then recreate filter chain from the memento popped from the undo stack. redo() would mirror this procedure. We would need two actions connected to undo and redo buttons with appropriate keyboard shortcuts.

An example workflow where i would like this disable option (and undo/redo would'nt work):
There are frequent camera switching in a video, one camera angle is dark, the other not so much. Also i want cropping, then fit to (a common) size. I save the segments with a mezzanine encoder, then at the end i append them then encode with the final codec.
Now after every few seconds i need to readjust the crop (large displacement), delete the color/intensity adjuster filters, and add another filter. With a disable option i can use two exclusive crop filter, where only minor adjustment would needed, and i could keep the color filters for each scenario.

This scenario is indeed much more complex than anything I could imagine. The enable/disable option would serve as a replacement for missing preset functionality then (both are not mutually exclusive).

The preview in the filter manager does not show the complete chain output, but the selected filter's.

It shows the output of the chain up to and including the selected filter (by default the last one). Actually, I figured this out a few years ago as a big surprise by reading code. I guess that adding the name of the selected filter to the window title would improve discoverability.
However, the new implementation creates IMHO a confusing element of not showing the actual output of the filter chain by default if the last filter is disabled (and it would never show the actual output if all active filters are disabled). Unsure how to solve this. Maybe by making the button always preview the final output, with preview of filters higher up in the chain available only via context menu? Could be perceived as a regression, I fear.

column20:
When seeking in the preview, and seek into the filter scope (its a keyframe, but not the acutal first frame), it will stuck with the wrong frame.
This is not an absolute fix, just an alleviation.

column21:
Thank you for finding the issue. Indeed, we cannot do much when we have sought to a frame past the start of the range.
In general, if something breaks on seek, the problem usually exists in the goToTime() implementation or in the lack thereof as here. Not taking due to wrong approach, but really thanks a lot for the bug report.

column20:
When seeking in the preview, and seek into the filter scope (its a keyframe, but not the acutal first frame), it will stuck with the wrong frame.
This is not an absolute fix, just an alleviation.
column21:
Why?
I try to rephrase the problem: the filter takes the first frame of the specified time window, when the play/saving process enter into the window. Then it will use this picture for blending. The issue only emerges, when the user seek in the preview of the filter chain.
During a linear process (eg. transcoding) it will work fine, even with the existing code.
I dont see another solution. If somehow you manage it to jump to the fist frame of the time window to take the frame, it will break the filter chain. The only valid solution would be decoding from the start of the video up to the first frame of the t.w., grab the frame, then reset everything to the beginning, and start decoding and filtering from the beginning.

column20:

column21:
The fundamental issue with missing the highway exit remains, of course, but methinks we should just clear the snapshot on seek.
(Well, your approach of clearing the snapshot when not in range has a benefit of easily keeping the good image when seeking within the filter range)

column20:
When seeking in the preview, and seek into the filter scope (its a keyframe, but not the acutal first frame), it will stuck with the wrong frame.
This is not an absolute fix, just an alleviation.
column21:
The problematic scenario:

seek past the start of the range (we get a wrong snapshot)
preview the output and stop short of the end of the range
seek to the start of the range.

As result we keep the wrong snapshot.

column20:
When seeking in the preview, and seek into the filter scope (its a keyframe, but not the acutal first frame), it will stuck with the wrong frame.
This is not an absolute fix, just an alleviation.
column21: It only keeps the wrong snapshot in the preview (transcoding not affected, as filter chain rebuilt), while the above scenario is unlikely. Reopening a preview (instatiating the next whatever filter, or opening the vfm's preview) will seek to zero, and will clear the snapshot (except if the range start at zero PTS).

column21:
Feels very risky. I get "unsorted double linked list corrupted" crash on deleting decoder (e.g. when closing Avidemux) attached to an appended video when hw decoder is used:

Load a H.264 video decodable with VDPAU
Append another H.264 video decodable with VDPAU
Start playback, stop playback
Close Avidemux = crash.


so there is still something that eats the memory (decoder?)

Sure, as libavcodec + libavutil keep decoded pictures needed for reference in refcounted buffers.
When hw accel is used, these buffers are hw surfaces pointed to by refHwImage in refDescriptor member of ADMImage in cacheElem. We manage these hw surfaces ourselves and set get_buffer2 callback in AVCodecContext to the pointer to our allocator and the free callback in av_buffer_create to our function to free a surface. Surfaces are recycled / destroyed when our ref counter has reached zero. With a shared cache, it might be that the second (third, etc.) decoder instance finds its surfaces gone.

Fixed for libavcodec, will fix uncompress() implementation of all other sw decoders later.

Now looks like ok.

Indeed, thanks, the crash is gone. I don't quite understand why it works yet.
Avidemux was really not using a per-video cache to its potential, I mean it should be possible at least to retain decoded images before a segment switch when the next segment has a different ref video, so that stepping backward across such segment boundaries could be faster.
If we go with a single common cache, what is the purpose of keeping different cache instances per video? Just to store int myInstance? Wouldn't it be more straightforward to move the cache into ADM_EditorSegment and do without any static vars? It makes a slightly bigger patch as the interface needs to be modified, but IMVHO this looks clearer.
editor-shared-cache-no-static-vars.patch.txt

With the commit: 6 GB RAM usage (so there is still something that eats the memory (decoder?) )
Mixed HW and SW decoded appending needs further confirmation.
PS: i managed to get VDPAU to work with my low end AMD card (no VP9). Appending a HW and a SW decoded file, there is no new error when using this shared cache.
PS+OT: Appending a HW and a SW decoded file, the SW decoded part not working, the editor shows the last HW decoded frame during seeking/playing in the SW decoded part. Same behaviour with 2.7.6 appimage.
column21:
I don't quite understand why it works yet.

I'm not 100% sure, but i think the problem was, hw ADM_images were reused without proper cleaning/releasing.

I mean it should be possible at least to retain decoded images before a segment switch when the next segment has a different ref video, so that stepping backward across such segment boundaries could be faster.

IMHO it is diminishing return. What would be really nice, if it could retain between segments in the same ref video.

If we go with a single common cache, what is the purpose of keeping different cache instances per video? Just to store int myInstance? Wouldn't it be more straightforward to move the cache into ADM_EditorSegment and do without any static vars? It makes a slightly bigger patch as the interface needs to be modified, but IMVHO this looks clearer.

I'm not an expert in object oriented programming (i only started using oop and c++ back in january, to improve the usability of this software), but i think this way follows the encapsulation principle  more strictly. And if it turns out to be problematic, reverting is easier.
But i'm not insisting to my solution. If you think the other way better, lets go with that.
PS: my ulterior motive here is to make way a possible increase in EDITOR_CACHE_MAX_SIZE, and consequently to the increase  of the upper limit of the editor cache size preference :-)

PS: i managed to get VDPAU to work with my low end AMD card (no VP9). Appending a HW and a SW decoded file, there is no new error when using this shared cache.

column21:
only started using oop and c++ back in january

This is pretty amazing.

And if it turns out to be problematic, reverting is easier.

I'd try to find a solution which can be switched between non-shared and shared mode using a define at compile time or even a preference at runtime.

my ulterior motive here is to make way a possible increase in EDITOR_CACHE_MAX_SIZE, and consequently to the increase of the upper limit of the editor cache size preference :-)

I fear I have to (partially) disappoint you as the main obstacle – limited hw resources when a hw decoder is used – is not alleviated by sharing a cache, e.g. with VDPAU, we still have to allocate at least cache_size + nb_ref_frames surfaces per decoder instance, i.e. per video. I don't know yet whether we can safely destroy some surfaces (currently we destroy them later when the decoder instance has been deleted) . Even if it turns out that we can do it for VDPAU, this is definitely impossible with DXVA2 where the entire pool of surfaces needs to be allocated upfront.

column21:
I fear I have to (partially) disappoint you as the main obstacle – limited hw resources when a hw decoder is used – is not alleviated by sharing a cache, e.g. with VDPAU, we still have to allocate at least cache_size + nb_ref_frames surfaces per decoder instance, i.e. per video. I don't know yet whether we can safely destroy some surfaces (currently we destroy them later when the decoder instance has been deleted) . Even if it turns out that we can do it for VDPAU, this is definitely impossible with DXVA2 where the entire pool of surfaces needs to be allocated upfront.

Caching matters mostly when using sw decoders. Would it be possible that cache size preference is used only when hw acceleration disabled? HW decoders are pretty fast, and can go with small cache size, so it could be even a hard define.
The optimal cache size would be to fit an entire GOP, but obviously that not realistic. But the current upper limit is too small.

I'd try to find a solution which can be switched between non-shared and shared mode using a define at compile time or even a preference at runtime.

I think it can be achieved inside the cache class, with a boolean parameter at the contructor.

column21:
Caching matters mostly when using sw decoders. Would it be possible that cache size preference is used only when hw acceleration disabled?

While technically possible, wouldn't it be an awfully awkward design? Especially considering that enabling hw accelerated decoding doesn't mean that a particular video can be decoded in hardware. This would also motivate users to keep hw decoding disabled, which is a bad thing.

The optimal cache size would be to fit an entire GOP

For optimal results, two GOPs  :-)

I think it can be achieved inside the cache class, with a boolean parameter at the contructor.

I thought It would go into ADM_EditorSegment::addReferenceVideo with a small change to ADM_EditorSegment::deleteAll, without EditorCache needing to know anything about its purpose.

column20:
Makes marker info available for the filters.
Those filters, that change duration, also adjust the marker infos.
Partial filter overwrite marker infos with start stop times, if the son filter opened for configuration.
The main goal here:
Filter dialog seeks to markerA upon opening the filter for configuration. Also this means in case of partial filter, it seeks to the start time of the partial filter (regardless of actual editor marker positions).
With the current infrastructure, the seek is only to a key frame.

column20:
Resizing or dragging the rubber band in the Crop filter is sluggish at 1080p and even more above.
Therefore i improved on ADM_flyDialogRgb (ADM_flyDialogRgb used only by Crop and Blacken border):

YUV->RGB conversion is performed only when necessary (Pts of the current image changed)
above 720p scaling is ADM_CS_FAST_BILINEAR instead of ADM_CS_BICUBIC

column21: Thanks!

Great, thank you.
With maximum size raised, do you have an idea what to do with the slider when the size specified by spinboxes exceeds the limit of 200%? It is a sort of a cognitive dissonance to see the percentage stuck at its upper limit while the true magnification is higher.
It doesn't need to be solved right now and in this PR, but I just feel uncomfortable with this detail.

I dont think there is a good solution, or that it should be:

increase the upper limit to an arbitrary limit (400%, 800% ?)
rescale the slider (it will jump back and forth as user type in the resolution)
?

IMHO the slider is just a convenient tool. Personally i have never used it :)

I see two possible ways to restore sanity: a) make the slider logarithmic with base derived from the highest possible magnification = MAXIMUM_SIZE / max(width,height)  with the center position assigned the raw value of 0 = 100% (may be a bit complicated to implement, no idea whether it will be comfortable to use) or b) remove the slider alltogether.
Thanks, I'll fix some trivial stuff like broken frame flags myself.

Did you select the right soundcard with the F6 key? Did you try a live system with more recent kernel?
I just realized that when I select an Alsa* output in Avidemux, Avidemux controls the master volume for all applications. I am not sure whether it is a desired behavior or a fixworthy bug. Probably the latter or an artifact of PulseAudio emulation, the volume control for the CoreAudio output on macOS affects the volume level for Avidemux only, similar to this soft volume solution for PAS (which works great).
I feel torn about this change, I personally never missed a volume control in Avidemux with PAS on Linux, rather enjoyed the space freed. Application-specific volume levels can be set in gnome-control-center, they persist at least for a GNOME session.

column21:
The vu meter bars were too thin, but it is possibly not the main issue.
Cutting the video to audio (ex: I need to edit out some video frames because of unwanted sound) is a struggle with Avidemux currently. The VU doesn't display much useful information when the video is stopped (audio players seems to do a lot better than Avidemux here). Something like a rolling average could be used, so a past loud still shows up in the vu on stopped video but with lesser amplitude.

column13: [T_vumeter] extend with bar width and overdrive level parameters
column20: imho the vu meter bars were too thin
column21:
The vu meter bars were too thin

I played with making them thicker quite a long time ago and discarded such attempts for visual reasons (probably personal taste issues). The bars must be twice as thick pixel-wise in HiDPI conditions. If they are not, this needs to be fixed.

but it is possibly not the main issue.

Indeed. The VU meter is a terrible resource hog. On macOS, it consumes more CPU power than decoding 720p@25fps H.264 in software. This was the reason I extended the effect of refresh cap setting to the VU meter, which rendered this widget even less useful.
The next issue is the VU meter being ahead of the audible sound due to internal buffering.
Indicated values are average (actually, mean square) over the last 5 ms, a peak or clipping detector might be a nice addition once the fundamental issues are solved.

column21: This PR is just an aesthetical improvment. With the widened bars it looks more similar to an actual LED bar VU meter.

column20:
I have replaced the volume control with hacked soft control (also fixed the indentations).
The original setVolume was a mess:

always used (at snd_mixer_attach) "hw:0", where ADEVICE should have been used
however a comment ("MEANX: Cannot use the real name, does not work with dmix") indicate it may wont work with "dmix" (i can not confirm it, alsa dmix audio output does not work on my system)
using ADEVICE, the volume control works, but it will change the global (==system-wide) volume, which is unacceptable.

I have also decreased the buffer size (1s -> 100ms), to reduce the lag between volume change action and effect.

column21: Do we have a race condition between sendData() and audioDeviceThreaded::getVolumeStats if data in the buffer both functions operate on gets altered in-place?

column21:
Soft volume application is protected by the mutex, so strictly speaking there is no race condition.
But there is a probability indeed, that getVolumeStats will determine an inaccurate metric.
This could be solved by adding a buffer to the Alsa device.

column21:
I tried to look into ALSA stuff. There are almost no descriptions or examples in the header files, similar to Avidemux. Very hard to use.
It turns out dmix expects SND_PCM_FORMAT_S32 only. I wonder whether this is specific to particular hardware or to ALSA version, but this explains why the dmix output doesn't work.
The original code in alsaAudioDevice::sendData doesn't seem to handle a theoretically valid scenario that snd_pcm_writei doesn't consume all the data passed to it in the buffer. I have no idea whether it is safe to cut this corner.
In most cases the volume is 100% or 0% (muted), does it bring any performance benefits to check for that and skip softvolume code?

I have also decreased the buffer size (1s -> 100ms), to reduce the lag between volume change action and effect.
column21:
The original code in alsaAudioDevice::sendData doesn't seem to handle a theoretically valid scenario that snd_pcm_writei doesn't consume all the data passed to it in the buffer. I have no idea whether it is safe to cut this corner.

I did not see complaints about that, so i assume it is safe.
It is set to blocking mode, and according to the manual:
If the blocking behaviour is selected and it is running, then routine waits until all requested frames are played or put to the playback ring buffer. The returned number of frames can be less only if a signal or underrun occurred.

In most cases the volume is 100% or 0% (muted), does it bring any performance benefits to check for that and skip softvolume code?

I will look into that.

column20:
I have replaced the volume control with hacked soft control (also fixed the indentations).
The original setVolume was a mess:

always used (at snd_mixer_attach) "hw:0", where ADEVICE should have been used
however a comment ("MEANX: Cannot use the real name, does not work with dmix") indicate it may wont work with "dmix" (i can not confirm it, alsa dmix audio output does not work on my system)
using ADEVICE, the volume control works, but it will change the global (==system-wide) volume, which is unacceptable.

I have also decreased the buffer size (1s -> 100ms), to reduce the lag between volume change action and effect.
column21:
Thank you for explaining why partial consumption of input data doesn't need to be handled.
Regarding the PR, there is an extraneous mutex.unlock() call in alsaAudioDevice::sendData() causing a flood of threading error messages. I'll merge once the mutex thing is fixed, thank you.
Only alsaDefault output (i.e. PulseAudio) works on my system, but this is not related to your changes.

column21: Yes, indeed. Thanks!

Thank you, looks great. Sure, this is the most straightforward way to get the job done and we have quite a few precedents in filter configuration, but did you evaluate using QMainWindow::saveState for everything the main window related? This would automatically cover not only the visibility of dock widgets, but additionally the position of the toolbar and the position and size of the window itself.
Just after a quick lookup, QMainWindow::saveState use some custom binary format, which would be (i think) hard to squeeze into the existing textual config file.

The example following the description of QMainWindow::saveState uses QSettings to store the returned QByteArray, this would bypass our own configuration infrastructure completely, if I am not mistaken. Not that the GTK GUI is about to be resurrected any time soon, but IMHO not tying the configuration to a particular GUI implementation and layout is a virtue.
Of course, making window size and position persist means changing the UI paradigm of Avidemux, but why not?

I have tried the suggested Qt stuff, and i did not liked it:

restoring the windows size is bad, if you had large window (but not maximized), restoring a large window without video looks goofy.
widget visibility is restored as expected, but in the View Menu / Toolbars the checkboxes are always checked after start.
restoring a state is sluggish, first you can see the normal sized window, for almost half a second, then it pop to the saved size.

restoring the windows size is bad, if you had large window (but not maximized), restoring a large window without video looks goofy.

This is very valid. As long as window size follows zoom level instead of adding scroll bars, we get all sorts of inconsistent and confusing behaviour.

widget visibility is restored as expected, but in the View Menu / Toolbars the checkboxes are always checked after start.

Could you please share the code? We might do something Qt doesn't expect. It can be also a Qt bug, in which case it would be interesting to see whether it persists with Qt6.

restoring a state is sluggish, first you can see the normal sized window, for almost half a second, then it pop to the saved size.

This might be related to us showing the main window in initGUI() prior to starting event loop in UI_RunApp() and doing hw accel probing and plugin loading in-between, which takes quite a lot of time.

Could you please share the code?

Well, i have scrapped those changes, but it wasnt very complicated:
For loading:
QSettings* settings = new QSettings(QDir::currentPath() + "/my_config_file.ini", QSettings::IniFormat); restoreGeometry(settings->value("geometry").toByteArray()); restoreState(settings->value("windowState").toByteArray());
For saving:
QSettings* settings = new QSettings(QDir::currentPath() + "/my_config_file.ini", QSettings::IniFormat); settings->setValue("geometry", saveGeometry()); settings->setValue("windowState", saveState()); settings->sync();
I have used them at the same location in UI_RunApp and UI_closeGui, as in my commit.

This might be related to us showing the main window in initGUI() prior to starting event loop in UI_RunApp() and doing hw accel probing and plugin loading in-between, which takes quite a lot of time.

Loading can not happen earlier, because some other part would override the loaded state (volume control visibility for example).
So to get it to work properly, IMHO a lot of changes should have been made, to achive miniscule gain over the proposed solution....

Portable mode doesn't allow to let QSettings decide which format to take and where to store the data, I would need to test on Windows the impact of a non-native format.
In general, QSettings seem to work great when GUI-specific configuration needs to be saved only per class rather than per instance. What do you think about the most suitable policy for visibility of rubber bands in various filters? If you hide it e.g. in the crop filter, do you expect it to be hidden in all crop filter instances once you open the configuration dialog?

What do you think about the most suitable policy for visibility of rubber bands in various filters? If you hide it e.g. in the crop filter, do you expect it to be hidden in all crop filter instances once you open the configuration dialog?

Its a tough question. Maybe its okay to expect hidden in the next filter instance. However, if i launch adm next time, i would expect it to show the rubber band.

I did noticed your new commit, there is a serious issue with it:
once you detach the toolbar (the one just under the menus), you can not (at least i cant) get docked again. Obviously no restart will fix it.

once you detach the toolbar (the one just under the menus), you can not (at least i cant) get docked again.

Resize the window to increase its height. The toolbar can be docked again then.
The whole is a WISP (work in slow progress), a function to reset GUI to default without manually deleting QtSettings.ini while Avidemux is not running is coming.

Maybe its okay to expect hidden in the next filter instance. However, if i launch adm next time, i would expect it to show the rubber band.

I struggle to understand why rubber band visibility in the crop filter should be different (should be reset) after application restart (even if it would be trivial to implement it). However, there is indeed a problem of the rubber band visibility being merely a usage hint in some filters (crop, blackenBorder) and an essential functionality in others (blur, mplayerDelogo). This means there is probably no "one size fits all" solution.
I've pushed two experimental commits to use QSettings for rubber band visibility in crop and blackenBorder, thus opening the Pandora's Box of inconsistency. I might revert both, haven't made my mind yet.
OT:
For something completely different: Would you like to join the Avidemux team on Slack for easier communication? I would try to send you the invitation for the email address mentioned in your commit headers then.

I struggle to understand why rubber band visibility in the crop filter should be different (should be reset) after application restart

In an editing session its o.k. because i will remember if i have turned if off. But next time i open the software it is shocking to me, when i open the crop filter and i dont see the rubber band.

Would you like to join the Avidemux team on Slack for easier communication?

O.k. However i will have less free time for this purpose in the future as it looks like things are turning back to normal again after this pandemic turmoil.

In an editing session its o.k. because i will remember if i have turned if off. But next time i open the software it is shocking to me, when i open the crop filter and i dont see the rubber band.

Done, quick & dirty style, export ADM_QT_DROP_SETTINGS=1 to get the desired behaviour.

O.k. However i will have less free time for this purpose in the future as it looks like things are turning back to normal again after this pandemic turmoil.

column20:
its experimental / far from perfect, it does not handle large motion well...
it is significantly faster than ffmpeg's minterpolate, but quality lacks behind.
however, if there are no large motions (eg. 20fps->60fps, 30fps->60fps) it is better most of the time than the "Blend" interpolation.
so dont try 1..2..5 fps->60fps conversion :)
there is no scene change detection. visible artifacts can occur.
overall, its not bad for a two afternoon job :)
i dont know cmake at all, so it was a little struggle to make CMakeLists.txt work, i hope its okay in the current state.

column21:
I apologize for the delays.
I use
INCLUDE(vf_plugin)

SET(ADM_vf_resampleFps_SRCS ADM_vidResampleFPS.cpp motin.cpp)

IF(DO_COMMON)
    include(admCheckThreads)
ENDIF(DO_COMMON)

ADD_VIDEO_FILTER(ADM_vf_resampleFps ${ADM_vf_resampleFps_SRCS})
INIT_VIDEO_FILTER(ADM_vf_resampleFps)
INSTALL_VIDEO_FILTER(ADM_vf_resampleFps)

IF(DO_COMMON)
    ADM_LINK_THREAD(ADM_vf_resampleFps)
ENDIF(DO_COMMON)

as CMakeLists.txt to build the enhanced resampleFps filter. I haven't tried cross-compilation and building on macOS yet (and I cannot test MSVC, obviously).
The preference FEATURES_THREADING_LAVC is not meant to control anything beyond the scope hinted by its name, i.e. it should not be used to control multi-threading in components other than libavcodec-based video decoders. It is also currently always set to 1 (single thread) when hw accelerated decoding is used.

overall, its not bad for a two afternoon job :)

It is outright amazing. However, the performance with a 654x480 sample and multi-threading hardcoded to 2 threads (my PC has a dual-core CPU) is 10 fps and 8 fps with multi-threading disabled. My feeling is that when it is that slow, it doesn't matter that it is faster than minterpolate. Personally, I would prefer going for maximum quality no matter how slow, else it feels like finding a middle ground between exiting a highway and continuing straight ahead.

However, the performance with a 654x480 sample and multi-threading hardcoded to 2 threads (my PC has a dual-core CPU) is 10 fps and 8 fps with multi-threading disabled.

I had around 35 fps at the mentioned 720p (29.97->60 fps) conversion. With the new commit, i can get 50 fps.

My feeling is that when it is that slow, it doesn't matter that it is faster than minterpolate.

IMHO 3-4 fps vs 50 fps is a BIG difference.

Personally, I would prefer going for maximum quality no matter how slow,

My first attempt was, to port/use minterpolate, but it would be very hard. If someone will port that, it could be a 4th option, and the user could decide between a fast and a slow (but better quality) motion interpolation.

else it feels like finding a middle ground between exiting a highway and continuing straight ahead.

Continuing the "car metaphore", quality-wise the Blend option is a wheelchair, my "Motin" is a scooter, and minterpolate is a regular car. (Fps-wise its in reverse :) )

Thank you very much. I pulled it, we'll see what breaks. Please keep maintaining the new feature, I cannot do it for you :-)
The quality is indeed better, it is worth a drop of speed to 3 fps with my sample, IMHO.
Of course, all the motion estimation cannot perform miracles, i.e. handle the image of moving bow of a string player rapidly changing strings back and forth. When resampled from almost 1001/30000 to strictly 1001/30000 with ME, you see two bow tips. In the original video, there is no temporal blending, all clean :-)

Continuing the "car metaphore"

There was actually no car metaphore involved, purely the problem of policy. An example of a situation where an agreement based on a trade off (without broadening the scope of negotiotions) is much worse than no agreement at all.

column20: related bugfix in changeFps
column21:
Regarding 1000 as fps limit, I wonder, what is the use case? Is there any hardware around capable of playing high-fps content beyond, say, 240 fps?

There are already displays with 360 Hz refresh rate, so you can think of this limit as future proofing.
Aside from that, if you want to make a slow motion video with motion interpolation, now you can do something like Resample fps (60 -> 960) + Change fps (960 -> 60).

I remember there was issues reported about unresponsive UI during playback (mostly on windoze).

https://avidemux.org/smif/index.php?topic=19231.0
I compared a build containing this patch to a build without it on Linux (NVIDIA), Windows 10 and Windows 7 using a 60 fps 720p sample and didn't see any difference, both were sufficiently responsive. Haven't tested on Linux/Intel yet.
At least, this patch doesn't do any harm. I'll merge it and try to get some feedback once nightlies get refreshed.

column20:
I remember there was issues reported about unresponsive UI during playback (mostly on windoze).
I have tested it by limiting adm to single core and playing demanding content, i saw some delayed (max 1 sec) response to play stop action.
This patch should fix it, but i can not test it on other platform.
column21:
I couldnt myself replicate a larger unresponsiveness.
But looking at the code, i could imagine a scenario, where the decoder barely keeps up with the desired rate, then
if(systemTime>movieTime) // We are late, the current PTS is after current closk
would be almost never met, because we are just in time, and therefore
while(delta > 10)
would also never run, consequently there wouldnt be any UI_purge() call, which is required to QT do its job.

column20:
I remember there was issues reported about unresponsive UI during playback (mostly on windoze).

This patch should fix it, but i can not test it on other platform.
column21:
Indeed, this must have been exactly the reason we ended up sometimes with unresponsive GUI. After a few attempts, I could reproduce the issue on Linux/Intel with an older build, but not with a current one, no matter how hard I tried. Forcing a minimum GUI refresh rate of 30 Hz has fixed the bug.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much.

column20: give feedback during navigation
column21: give feedback during navigation

column20: give feedback during navigation
column21:
Great, thank you.
A luxury wish: would it be possible to override cursor only if the wait exceeds some threshold? Keeping e.g. the next frame button pressed produces a lot of flicker from changing the cursor.

column20: give feedback during navigation
column21:
A luxury wish: would it be possible to override cursor only if the wait exceeds some threshold?

That was my first attempt (with QTimer::singleshot), but it does not worked. I suspect the cause is, Qt internal stuff is not updated, while ffmpeg do the magic in the background.

column20: give feedback during navigation
column21:
Indeed, looks like a tough nut to crack. The slot for timeout() signal of a QTimer is not called before actionSlot() is completed.
There is more stuff I don't fully understand yet, e.g. NAVIGATION_ACTION_LOCK_THRESHOLD is almost never exceeded. With an else branch added to the condition if (actionLock<=NAVIGATION_ACTION_LOCK_THRESHOLD), it is almost never reached.
busyCntr gets slowly incremented until it reaches NAVIGATION_ACTION_LOCK_THRESHOLD, then decremented to zero within a millisecond, resulting in cursor flickering briefly every NAVIGATION_ACTION_LOCK_THRESHOLD steps.

column20: give feedback during navigation
column21:
There is more stuff I don't fully understand yet, e.g. NAVIGATION_ACTION_LOCK_THRESHOLD is almost never exceeded. With an else branch added to the condition if (actionLock<=NAVIGATION_ACTION_LOCK_THRESHOLD), it is almost never reached.

That is interesting, because otherwise it stops piling up unserviced key events.
Maybe the flickering could be eliminated, by adding delay after busyCntr back to zero.

column20: give feedback during navigation
give feedback during navigation
column21:
To drain accumulating signals, we could evaluate the currently unused static admMutex singleThread in HandleAction() in gui_main.cpp
instead of solving it in Qt.

That would be a bad idea. On the one hand the mutex is not unused, it is the sole guard that provides the in-order execution of actions; on the other this would discard every action while the sole one is serviced. The NAVIGATION_ACTION_LOCK_THRESHOLD makes possibble to queue a limited number of action (for example if i want to go forward 3 frames, and i press right arrow key three times, using the mutex it could discard 2 keypress).


Maybe the flickering could be eliminated, by adding delay after busyCntr back to zero.



Could you please elaborate?

See the new commit :)

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21: Play a short section backward.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
Thank you very much, a couple of points after a cursory try-out:

The build fails on macOS for the trivial reason of missing ADM_coreVideoFilter.h include in cli/DIA_reverse.cpp (with DIA_coreToolkit.h and math.h includes being unneeded).
I can imagine that Avidemux toolkit is still too limited to implement the configuration dialog in toolkit instead of directly in Qt. But in this case it might be tempting to extend the toolkit, at least middle-term, IMHO.
When previewing the filter in the main window, audio is strongly out of sync (delayed!) after the end of filter scope. Audio being ahead of video is easily possible with slow filters, but getting behind is probably a bug.
When starting preview in the main window from a point within the range, the filter seems to determine the range from relative time rather than absolute. Unsure, though. Something is not right here.
Preview after seek into the range in the filter manager which is acknowledged as not working, would be nice to have.
I wonder whether the cache file location and name could be made user-defined.
QString text = QString(QT_TRANSLATE_NOOP("reverse","Time scope: "));  and similar cases: I guess the constructor in assignment is redundant.
Would it be possible to catch malloc failure during preview rather than assert and crash?

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
The build fails on macOS for the trivial reason of missing ADM_coreVideoFilter.h include in cli/DIA_reverse.cpp (with DIA_coreToolkit.h and math.h includes being unneeded).

Should be fixed

When previewing the filter in the main window, audio is strongly out of sync (delayed!) after the end of filter scope. Audio being ahead of video is easily possible with slow filters, but getting behind is probably a bug.

I tried the scenario with more than one video. Here works as expected, after the scope the audio is in sync with the video.

When starting preview in the main window from a point within the range, the filter seems to determine the range from relative time rather than absolute. Unsure, though. Something is not right here.

I think it is, due to not gettting a call to goToTime, which would invalidate the filter. IDK if this could be fixed at all.

Preview after seek into the range in the filter manager which is acknowledged as not working, would be nice to have.

I dont think it would be possible.

I wonder whether the cache file location and name could be made user-defined.

It is a temporary file, imho it is more convenient this way. Also it follows the convention of the .idx files (of .ts files).

Would it be possible to catch malloc failure during preview rather than assert and crash?

I will think about it.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
I think, the preview problems could be addressed, as warn the users, not use previews after instantiating this filter.
Without proper backend support the preview issues couldnt be addressed, but IMHO with the current time based backend it wont be possible (as opposed to pre-2.6 frame based backend.)
Malloc failures could be indicated by GUI_Error_HIG(). Does it works in cli mode? What sould we do, if malloc fails during encoding?

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
When starting preview in the main window from a point within the range, the filter seems to determine the range from relative time rather than absolute. Unsure, though. Something is not right here.

I have figured this out: somehow the handed over image PTS start at zero when start palying filtered video in the main window, regardless of what is should be.
You can easily test it, just instantiate a Misc./PrintInfo filter. It also will show the incorrect PTS.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
somehow the handed over image PTS start at zero when start palying filtered video in the main window, regardless of what is should be.

I think this is the expected behaviour, pts are relative to the bridge range. There are functions to get the absolute timing.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
Fixed the absolute Pts issue, warning message get refined.
Show green screen if start playing inside the time scope.
I've managed to get the audio desync issue. It happens when the buffering takes more times, and the audio play get suspended during that. If it can buffer (decode) fast enough, audio stay in sync after the filter's scope.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
I have tried GUI_Error_HIG(), but it does not work even in main window's preview.
Do you have a better idea for handling malloc failure?

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
So it looks like i have figured it out, how to replace assert with a graceful solution.
If error happens, it returns with a last frame colored red + short error message, also write message to the log, then at the next  getNextFrame call returns false and interrupts play or encoding.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
The malloc behaviour on macOS is troublesome: it doesn't fail but the system simply swaps to death trying to reverse a 3 minutes long 1080p@50fps video at default settings except of buffering to memory instead of to a file (well, I managed to kill Avidemux as it passed through ~17 GiB of memory on a MBP with 8 GiB RAM).
I think the design is not viable on macOS :-(

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
I think the design is not viable on macOS :-(

Did the estimated RAM usage (at the filter dialog) correlated with the above number?
If yes, then it is a user error by ignoring the warnings :)

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
Did the estimated RAM usage (at the filter dialog) correlated with the above number?

No, it was completely impossibly high for this machine (~28 GiB). The goal was to trigger a malloc failure.

If yes, then it is a user error by ignoring the warnings :)

Yes and no. User errors need to be tested too :) It is fine to risk an app crash / app being killed by an OOM guard or so. But inducing a system hang, potentially destroying important work in other applications is unacceptable, no matter what.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21: Memory handling is similar on Linux, it allows allocate more memory than actual RAM, because technially swap is also memory (albeit very slow). Escalate the situation further, the system could allow allocation of even larger chunk, more than RAM+swap, due to overcommitting.

column20: Play a short section backward.
column21:
On that macOS system, there was not enough disk space to accomodate the necessary swap, so I hoped the operation to fail outright. There is some macOS-specific stuff like memory compression which may have played a role, however.
Either way, this doesn't make the situation easier.

the preview dialog on macOS had the maximize button all the time

No wonder, I am the culprit: c598494
Last night, I could test a little on Linux. Reflagging dialog window as a normal window results in a very weird behaviour of gnome-shell 3.38.5 / mutter: such a filter preview window can be moved to another workspace, but switching workspaces back becomes impossible(?!) unless preview is closed. Will test with the current gnome-shell and Qt6 later.
Definitely not going the path of adding a preference, QSetting would be fine because filter-specific, but the problem are window flags and how Qt and window managers handle this, else I would suggest the private patch below (GitHub doesn't accept .patch, great, thus renamed to .patch.txt).
video-filter-preview-persistent-maximize.patch.txt

column21:
How about a preference to open filters as Qt::dialog or Qt::window?

I don't think the feature is significant enough to justify introduction of broken behaviour* which unfortunately ensues at least with gnome-shell, the current version included, when moving modal windows not flagged as a dialog to a different workspace.
*) It is impossible to switch to the workspace containing Avidemux main window once filter preview has been moved to a different workspace as long as the filter preview remains open on a different workspace.

Then Qsetting could could restore size if pref set to Qt::window.

I haven't found a way to restore the parent widget size / window geometry from ADM_flyDialog, that turned out to be tricky. Restoring window state was easy.
By the way, the part of qtRegisterDialog which should ensure that all windows are open as dialogs is buggy, it should have been
        if ((flags & Qt::Dialog) == Qt::Dialog)
            isDialog = true;

This bug was the reason why the proposed patch was working in the first place ;-D

column13: [hdr] config HDR tone mapping from dedicated dialog
column20:
HDR tone mapping config (method, saturation, boost) available from the "Video" menu.
In Preferences only default method and target luminance (which could even be a hidden hard coded constant, but keep anyway) are kept.
The config is written out to the python file(s) as "adm.setHDRConfig", so it also can be used in batch processing.
Only missing part is the tinyPy readback of "adm.setHDRConfig".

Great, thanks!
While testing, I realized that no matter how infrequently users may need these features, the removal of the navigation buttons which I requested or at least suggested was a very bad idea. If there is even a short stretch of black pictures in the video, being forced to open menu for every single step is infuriating. This was driving me mad after 5 or 6 pictures already.
I understand that seeking to the next keyframe would help in such a situation, but nevertheless, even a brief feeling of getting stuck is awful.
I am very sorry, but we need to reinstate the buttons and eventually even assign keyboard shortcuts.
I have no problem with the buttons reinstated. It was removed due to user complaints, that one of the pairs of buttons next to it were shifted, when cut point buttons were added.

column20: go to the prev key frame, check forward up to the current position, if not found set the keyframe as the current position, then repeat

column20: go to the prev key frame, check forward up to the current position, if not found set the keyframe as the current position, then repeat
column21:
Thank you. In most real world cases, the bet that there will be a black frame much closer to the current position than to the start of the video might work (however, repeated seek to keyframes is pretty expensive compared to sequential decoding, so we need a good portion of luck with black frames to justify that).
There is one exotic but not unthinkable scenario where the new approach definitely doesn't work out: all-intra videos, sometimes used as an intermediate stage of editing (for this purpose, you even contributed x264 Mezzanine preset).
Such videos could be detected during the search among presumably cached pictures: check the flags and if all 6 are keyframes, don' try the new strategy.

In any case, I would suggest delaying this topic until the next release cycle.

column13: [ADM_preview] omit error message if can not go to the next/prev keyframe, but there is none to go to
column20: i find annoying, when it pops up error message, while at the beginning or at the end of the video
column21:
Please imagine a somewhat damaged video with a keyframe missing a timestamp so that getNKFramePTS() fails. Alternatively, it might be also a video completely without keyframes after the first one (such a stream may be impractical, but otherwise entirely valid). How should we let the user know that she really cannot seek to the next keyframe and hammering the up or down arrow key won't help?
Another, much more frequent case might be a relatively short video with very long GOPs. The user sees that there is still a significant distance before the end of the navigation slider range, but she cannot advance to the next keyframe. A reason to get mad? Sure!
I don't want to defend the current error message as it conveys zero information about the background of the seek failure, but it at least provides assurance that further attempts to go to the next keyframe will be futile.

column13: [ADM_preview] omit error message if can not go to the next/prev keyframe, but there is none to go to
column20: i find annoying, when it pops up error message, while at the beginning or at the end of the video
column21:
I understand the reasoning. But the current solution is also maddening. The popup error message is annoying not just because it interrupts the editing process, but suddenly the user can not discern that it means their video is damaged, or just reached the end/begining. (In case of undecodable key frame you get the error, can't go through with nextkeyframe, but can be jumped over with the navigation slider.)
Maybe add a user interface preference? Or extend the Message level preference?

column13: [ADM_threadQueue] bugfix + exclusive access for state variable
column20:
-fix stopping issue  (half second delay) during playback (which resulted very slow navigation during play)
-always access threadState exclusively
column21:
Quoting from the top answer at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2484980/why-is-volatile-not-considered-useful-in-multithreaded-c-or-c-programming.
"volatile does not guarantee that no reordering takes place. Assume that we use a volatile variable as a flag to indicate whether or not some data is ready to be read. In our code, we simply set the flag after preparing the data, so all looks fine. But what if the instructions are reordered so the flag is set first?"

column21:
On Fedora, Avidemux stdout output is automatically written to user's journal if not run in a TTY (this is why I always run Avidemux in a TTY). Is it not the case on yours?
On Windows and macOS, stdout is redirected to file, which can be examined in a text editor from Avidemux GUI (on Windows) or universally with any plain text viewer when the user has basic filesystem navigation skills.
The real problem arises from this log file rapidly growing (sometimes by > 1 MiB per second) from careless use of printf and its wrappers (we had requests, pretty valid, to let users disable logging alltogether) causing a DoS situation or filling up the disk as the worst case.
Adding an internal viewer is surely a good thing (it can be handy in normal situations not involving crashes), I just wonder what could be done to address the big issue.

At the same time, plain printf would remain untouched (printf cannot be universally replaced with ADM_info in Avidemux code, they serve different purposes).

Well, printf shouldnt be used AT ALL. Those are 99% leftovers from ancient lazy debugging attempts. ADM_info, ADM_warning and ADM_error should be used everywhere.

column13: [debug] internal logging; view log in GUI; verbose logging infrastructure
column20:
internal logging + GUI --> unreproducible errors can be investigated (if Avidemux not started in a terminal)
verbose logging infrastructure --> in the future majority of  #ifdef ADM_DEBUG  or #if0 aprint  gated loggings can be replaced, allowing on the fly enable/disable to investigate bugs, without recompiling. also would be useful in case unreproducible errors.
column21:
I dont know anything about that. (Ubuntu based)

Launch Avidemux via .desktop file (from start menu, dock, whatever), then run journalctl in the terminal.

But it would not require replacing every such, just the polluting ones.

If it were not that hard to identify the messages which can become repeated offenders...

Well, printf shouldnt be used AT ALL. Those are 99% leftovers from ancient lazy debugging attempts. ADM_info, ADM_warning and ADM_error should be used everywhere.

They have different features. ADM_info is unusable with long lines like the list of OpenGL extensions in UI_Qt4InitGl() or when full control of formatting is needed.

column21:
Probably a minor inconvenience seen at least with Qt 6.2.2, but it might still matter when this switch is meant to be on-the-fly:

STR:

Switch to dark theme (fusion with custom palette)
Restart Avidemux
Switch to light theme, don't restart Avidemux yet
Open drop-down menu of any of the combo boxes in the codec widget

The same happens on a switch from light to dark, just that the barely visible text is dark on dark. The text in the time indicator has wrong color too.
Restarting Avidemux rectifies that.
I haven't tried yet whether this will work on-the-fly at all, but I personally don't like the idea of allowing users to switch Qt theme away from the native one on non-Linux platforms. If only Apple didn't break native Qt theme on almost every macOS upgrade...

column20: +fix limited range YCbCr to RGB conversion
column21: +fix limited range YCbCr to RGB conversion

column20: +fix limited range YCbCr to RGB conversion
column21:
An amazing improvement, visually at least, thank you very much! Much closer to what feels "right" with my hardware (which is how it looks when samples are played by mpv with --vo=gpu). I do see some green tint with non-clipping RGB adaptive modes for the "The World in HDR" 10-bit AV1 sample. With all samples, the clipping mode is the one which produces the best – really perfect looking – results, except in areas where actual clipping occurs. With other RGB adaptive modes, I need to apply a lot of boost (at least 1.8 with Reinhard, 2 with Hable), even after reducing target luminance to values below 40.
One big request: could you please replace all the magic numbers with maintainable alternatives or at least add comments (probably a lot of comments) explaining the values used?
Once merged, do we still need the previous, inferior options?

column20: +fix limited range YCbCr to RGB conversion
column21:
With all samples, the clipping mode is the one which produces the best – really perfect looking – results, except in areas where actual clipping occurs.

This is a known fact. Clipping is the best to preserves colors, others not.
the "hue and saturation shifts" (really mostly saturation shifts) resulting from applying nonlinear curves per channel are an important feature, not a bug.
Otherwise there is still something wrong with the colors, but have not figured out why.

With other RGB adaptive modes, I need to apply a lot of boost (at least 1.8 with Reinhard, 2 with Hable), even after reducing target luminance to values below 40.

With my samples those boost values are too much, so there is no good setting, the final adjusments have to be made by the user. The adaptivity really just means, that try to be reasonably good simultaneously at brigth and dark scenes. Target luminance probably has little effect.

One big request: could you please replace all the magic numbers with maintainable alternatives or at least add comments (probably a lot of comments) explaining the values used?

Those are really magic numbers :'-D

Once merged, do we still need the previous, inferior options?

Do you mean the non adaptive rgb mappers? There could be use cases, i think...

column20: +fix limited range YCbCr to RGB conversion
column21:
Those are really magic numbers :'-D

This means, the PR provides better working unmaintainable code vs worse working unmaintainable code, thus merged.


Once merged, do we still need the previous, inferior options?

Do you mean the non adaptive rgb mappers? There could be use cases, i think...

Unless the use cases are critically important, I'd advocate keeping the menu options while silently upgrading the functionality.

I wanted to change the library as least as possible. This could make easier to pull in upstream patches in the future (less chanche of merge conflicts).

column20:
incorporate rubberband
replace Film2Pal & Pal2Film with the new stretcher (keeps pitch)
custom frame rate option (with pitch change option)
custom frame rate: automagic tempo value  (opening the audio filter config dialog, temporarily video filter chain created, to determine original and filtered duration)

PS: not tested/built on win or mac
column21:
Build & basic function verified for Apple/arm64 and for MinGW. I think further refinements, if desired and agreed, can be performed in a new PR after merge.
Thanks a lot!

column13: [UI] QSettings option for opening filter dialogs maximized
column20:
View menu / Filters / Open filter dialogs maximized
If enabled, it can spare the manual resizing of filter's dialogs every time.

column20:
Filter specific preferences can be set through filter's UI.
Default resizer algorithm can be changed in resize, fitToSize & zoom
Default padding can be changed in fitToSize & zoom
Rubber band visibility can be changed in preferences of zoom, crop & blackenBorder
